qas.question: Recognizing the different characteristics of various diseases is one way to do what?

answers.text: prevent or slow down the transmission of infectious diseases

qas.question: What are some critical disease characteristics that should be evaluated?

answers.text: virulence, distance traveled by victims, and level of contagiousness

qas.question: What virus' strains incapacitate their victims extremely quickly before killing them?
Why is the initial stage of Ebola not very contagious?
What does the low virulence of HIV allow victims to do?
What does recognizing the different characteristics of various diseases allow someone to increase?

plausible_answers.text: virulence, distance traveled by victims, and level of contagiousness

qas.question: What are some critical disease characteristics that should not be evaluated?
What virus' strains strengthen their victims extremely quickly before killing them?
Why is the initial stage of Ebola so contagious?
What does the extreme virulence of HIV allow victims to do?

context: One of the ways to <a0_0>prevent or slow down <b5_0>the transmission of infectious diseases<b5_0/><a0_0/> is to recognize the different characteristics of various diseases. Some critical disease characteristics that should be evaluated include <a1_0><b6_0>virulence, distance traveled by victims, and level of contagiousness<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The human strains of <a2_0>Ebola<a2_0/> virus, for example, incapacitate their victims extremely quickly and kill them soon after. As a result, the victims of this disease do not have the opportunity to travel very far from the initial infection zone. Also, this virus must spread through skin lesions or permeable membranes such as the eye. Thus, the initial stage of Ebola is not very contagious since its <a3_0><b8_0>victims experience only internal hemorrhaging<b8_0/><a3_0/>. As a result of the above features, the spread of <b7_0>Ebola<b7_0/> is very rapid and usually stays within a relatively confined geographical area. In contrast, the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) kills its victims very slowly by attacking their immune system. As a result, many of its victims transmit the virus to other individuals before even realizing that they are carrying the disease. Also, the relatively low virulence allows its victims to <a4_0><b9_0>travel long distances<b9_0/><a4_0/>, increasing the likelihood of an epidemic.
